intro: Trembleya rhynanthera, commonly known as the golden orchid, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its striking golden-yellow petals and sepals. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte, attaching itself to trees in humid, shaded environments. Its flowers bloom during the warmer months, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The botanical features of Trembleya rhynanthera make it a visually striking and ecologically significant species in its native habitat.
